I must dispatch this business upon earth
before I take that journey, I will to my brother for his aid or counsel;
So wronged; o heaven put armour on my spirit
her body I will place in her first rest
or in the attempt lock death into my breast --

stage.l: Enter Votarius with Anselmus the Husband.

sp.l: you shall stand here my lord unseen, and here all
do I deal now like a right friend with you?
like a most faithful.
you shall have her mind even as it comes to me
though I undo her by it, your friendship sir
is the sweet mistress that I only serve,
I prize the roughness of a man's embrace
before the soft lips of a hundred ladies
and that is an honest mind of thee
lock yourself sir
into that closet and be sure none see you
trust not a creature, we will have all run clear
even as the heart affords it
it is a match Sir. --
troth he says true there, it is a match indeed
he does not know the strength of his own words
for if he did there were no mastering of him!
has cleft the pin in two with a blind man's eyes
though I shoot wide, I will Cousin him of the game --
dost thou see thine enemy walk
I would I did not
prithee rest quiet man, I have feed one for him
a trusty Catchpole too that will be sure of him,
thou knowest this gallery well it is at thy use now
it has been at mine full often, thou mayst sit
like a most private gallant in yon corner
see all the play and never
be seen thyself
therefore I chose it
thou shalt see my lady
play her part naturally, more to the life
than she is aware of
there must I be pleased,
thou art one of the Actors, thou wilt be mist anon,
alas a woman's action is always ready
yet I will down now I think on it --
do it is time i'faith
I know not yet where I should plant belief
I am so strangely tossed, between two tales,
I am told by my wives woman the deed is done
and in Votarius tongue, it is yet to come,
the Castle is but upon yielding yet
it is not delivered up, well, we shall find
the mystery shortly, I will entertain
the patience of a prisoner in the mean time.
Is all set ready wench
push, madam, all
Tell not me so, she lives not for a lady
that has less peace than I
nay good sweet madam
you would not think how much this passion alters you,
It drinks up all the beauty of your cheek
I promise you madam you have lost much blood,
let it draw death upon me, for till then
I shall be mistress of no true content
who could endure hourly temptation
and bare it as I do.
nay that is most certain
unless it were myself again, I can do it
I suffer the like daily, you should complain madam
which way, were that wisdom! prithee wench to whom
to him that makes all whole again, my lord
to one that if he be a kind good husband
will let you bear no more than you are able,
thou knowest not what thou speakest, why my lord is he
that gives him the house-freedom, all his boldness,
keeps him apurpose here to war with me
Now I hold wiser of my lord then so
he knows the world, he would not be so idle,
I speak sad truth to thee, I am not private
in mine own chamber such his impudence is
nay my repenting time is scarce blessed from him
he will offend my prayers
out upon him
I believe madam he is of no Religion
he serves my lord and that is enough for him
and pray upon poor ladies like myself.
there is all the gentleman's devotion!
marry the devil of hell give him his blessing
pray watch the door, and suffer none to trouble us
unless it be my lord
it was finely spoke that
my lord indeed is the most trouble to her,
now must I show a piece of service here;
how do I spend my days,
life shall I never
get higher than a ladies door-keeper!
I must be married as my lady is first
and then my maid may do as much for me
O miserable time, except my lord
do wake in honourable pity to me
and rid this vicious gamester from his house
whom I have checked so often, here I vow
I will imitate my noble sisters fate
late mistress to the worthy Gouianus
and cast away my life as he did hers,

stage.l: Enter Votarius to the doore within

sp.l: back, ye are too forward sir, there is no coming for you
how mistress len, my ladies smock woman
am I no farther in your duty yet?
duty! look for it of them you keep under sir
you will let me in
who would you speak withal
with the best lady you make Curtsy too
she will not speak with you
have you her mind
I scorn to take her answer of her broker
what is there, how now Sir, what is your business?
we see your boldness plain
I came to see your madam
farewell then, though it was Impudence too much
when I was private,
life he was born
to beggar all my patience;
I am bold
still to prefer my love -- your woman hears me not
where is modesty and honour? have I not thrice
answered thy lust
byrlady I think oftener
and darest thou yet look with temptation on us,
since nothing will prevail, come death, come vengeance
I will forget the weakness of my kind
and force thee from my chamber
how now lady!
uds life you prick me madam
prithee peace,
I will not hurt thee, -- will you yet begone sir,
he is upon going I think
madam, heart you deal false with me, o I feele it,
ye are a most treacherous lady! this thy glory?
my breast is all a-fire -- o --
ha ha ha --
ha? I believe her Constancy too late
confirmed even in the blood of my best friend
take thou my vengeance, thou bold perjurous strumpet
that durst accuse thy virtuous lady falsely;
o deadly poison after a sweet banquet
what make I here, I had forgot my heart,
I am an Actor too, and never thought on it
the blackness of this season cannot miss me
Sirrah, you, lord.
is he there! welcome Ruin
there is a life due to me in that bosom
for this poor gentlewoman.
and art thou then receiver?
I will pay thee largely slave for thy last scape

stage.l: They make a daungerous passe at one another
the Lady purposely runs betwene, and is kild

sp.l: I come Votarius
hold, if manhood guide thee
o what has fury done?
what has it done now?
why killed an honourable whore, that is all
villain I will seal that lie upon thy heart,
A Constant lady,
To the devil as could be,
heart must I prick you forward, either up
or sir I will take my chance, thou couldst kill her
without repenting, that deserved more pity
and spendest thy time and tears upon a Quean.
Slave!
that was deceived once in her own deceit!
As I am now, the poison I prepared
upon that weapon for mine enemies bosom
is bold to take acquaintance of my blood too
and serves us both to make up death withal
I ask no more of destiny but to fall
close by the chaste side of my virtuous mistress,
if all the treasure of my weeping strength
be left so wealthy but to purchase that
I have the dear wish of a great man's spirit,
yet favour me, o yet, I thank thee fate
I expire cheerfully and give death a smile --
o rage! I pity now mine enemies flesh
where should he be?
my lady sir will tell you
she is in her chamber here
o my lord
Peace! -- my honourable brother, madam, All --
so many dreadful deeds and not one tongue
left to proclaim them!
yes, here, if a voice
some minute long may satisfy your ear
I have that time allowed it
it is enough
bestow it quickly ere death snatch it from thee
that lord your brother, made his friend Votarius
to tempt his lady, she was won to lust,
the Act revealed here by her servingwoman,
but that wise close Adulteress stored with art
to pray upon the weakness of that lord
dissembled a great rage upon her love
and indeed killed him, which so won her husband
he slew this right discoverer in his fury,
who being my mistress I was moved in heart
to take some pains with him, and has paid me for it
As for the cunning lady I commend her,
she performed that which never woman tried
she ran upon two weapons and so died,
now you have all I hope I shall sleep quiet --
Is death so long acoming to mankind
it must be met halfways? Lass the full time
is (to eternity) but a minute, a --
was that so long to stay? o cruel speed;
there is few men pay their debts before their day
if they be ready at their time, it is well,
and but a few that are so, what strange haste
was made among these people! my heart weeps for it
go, bear those bodies to a place more comely;
Brother, I came for thy advice, but I
find thee so ill a Councillor to thyself
that I repent my pains and depart sighing,
the body of my love is still at Court
I am not well to think on it, the poor Spirit
was with me once again about it, Troth --
and I can put it off no more for shame
though I desire to have it haunt me still
and never to give
over it is so pleasing:
I must to court I have plighted my faith to it
it has opened me the way to the revenge
Tyrant I will rune thee on a dangerous shelf
though I be forced to fly this land myself.
In vain my Spirit wrestles with my blood
affection will be mistress here on earth,
the house is hers, the Soul is but a tenant,
I have tasked myself but with the Abstinence
of one poor hour, yet cannot conquer that
I cannot keep from sight of her so long
I starve mine eye too much, go bring her forth
as we have caused her body to be decked
in all the glorious Riches of our palace;
our mind has felt a famine for the time
All comfort has been dear and scarce with us
the times are altered since, strike on sweet harmony
A braver world comes toward us

stage.l: They bring the Body in a Chaire drest up in black veluet which setts out the
pailenes of the handes and face, And a faire Chayne of pearle crosse her brest
and the Crucyfex above it; He standes silent a while letting the Musique
play, becknyng the soldiers that bringe her in to make obeisaunce to her, and
he hym self makes a lowe honour to the body and kisses the hande

sp.l: O what is Beauty that is so much adored
A flattering glass that cozens her beholders,
one Night of death makes it look pale and horrid
The Dainty preserved flesh how soon it molders
To love it living it bewitcheth many
But after life is seldom heard of any.
By this hand, mere Idolatry, I make Curtsy
to my damnation, I have learnt so much
though I could never know the meaning yet
of all my latin prayers, nor never sought for it
how pleasing art thou to us even in death
I love thee yet, above all women living
and shall do seven year hence,
I can see nothing to be mended in thee
but the too constant paleness of thy cheek
I would give the kingdom, but to purchase there
the breadth of a red Rose, in natural colour,
and think it the best bargain, that ever king made yet,
but Fate is my hindrance,
And I must only rest content with Art
and that I will have in spite of it! -- is he come sir.
who my lord
dull! -- the fellow that we sent
for a Court schoolmaster, a Picture drawer
A ladies forenoon Tutor, is he come sir
not yet returned my lord
the fool belike
makes his choice carefully for so we charged him;
to fit our close deeds with some private hand,
It is no shame for thee most silent mistress
to stand in need of Art, when youth
and all thy warm friends has forsook thee,
women alive are glad to seek her friendship
to make up the fair number of their graces
or ells the reckoning would fall short sometimes
and servants would look out for better wages
he is come my lord.
depart then, is that he?
the privatest I could get my lord
o heaven marry patience to my spirit
give me a sober fury I beseech thee,
A rage that may not overcharge my blood
and do myself most hurt! it is strange to me
to see thee here at Court, and gone from hence
didst thou make haste, to leave the world for this?
and kept in the worst Corner!
o who dares play with destiny but he
that wears Security so thick upon him
the thought of Death and Hell cannot pierce through
it was circumspectly carried, leave us, go
be nearer sir, thou art much commended to us
it is the hand my lord Commends the workman
thou speakest both modesty and truth in that,
we need that Art that thou art master of
my king is Master both of that and me
look on yon face and tell me what it wants
which that sir!
that? what wants it!
troth my lord
some thousand years sleep, and a marble pillow
what is that! observe it still, All the best arts
hath the most fools and drunkards to their Masters,
thy apprehension has too gross a film
to be employed at Court; what colour wants she
by my troth all sir, I see none she has
nor none she cares for
I am overmatched here
A lower Chamber with less noise were kindlier
for her poor woman, whatsoever she was
but how if we be pleased to have it thus
and thou well hired to do what we command
is not your work for money?
yes my lord
I would not trust at Court if I could choose
let but thy Art hide death upon her face
that now looks fearefully on us, and but strive
to give our eye delight in that pale part
which draws so many pities from these springs
and thy reward for it shall outlast thy end,
and reach to thy friends fortunes, and his friend;
Say you so my lord, I will work out my heart then
but I will show Art enough
About it then
I never wished so seriously for health
after long sickness
A religious trembling shakes me by the hand
and bids me put by such unhallowed business
but revenge calls for it, and it must go forward
it is time the spirit of my love took rest
poor soul, it is weary, much abused and toiled
Could I now send for one to renew heat
within her bosom, that were a fine workman;
I should but too much love him, but alas
it is as unpossible for living fire
to take hold her, as for dead ashes
to burn back again
into the those hard tough bodies whence they fell,
life is removed from her now, as the warmth
of the bright Son from us when it makes winter,
and kills with unkind coldness, so is it yonder
and everlasting frost hangs now upon her
And as in such a season men will force
a heat into their bloods with exercise
in spite of extreme weather, so shall we
by art force beauty on yon ladies face
though Death sit frowning on it a storm of hail
to beat it off; our pleasure shall prevail
my lord
hast done so soon
that is as your grace
gives approbation
o she lives again
she will presently speak to me, keep her up
I will have her sown no more, there is treachery in it
does she not feele warm to thee
very little sir.
the heat wants cherishing then, our Arms and lips
shall labour life into her, wake sweet mistress
it is I that call thee at the door of life, -- ha?
I talk so long to death, I am sick myself
methinks an evil scent still follows me
may be it is nothing but the colour sir
that I laid on
is that so strong
yes faith sir,
it was the best poison I could get for money;
Gouianus?
o thou sacrilegious villain,
thou thief of rest, robber of monuments,
Cannot the body after funeral
sleep in the grave for thee? must it be raised
only to please the wickedness of thine eye!
does all things end with death and not thy lust?
hast thou devised a new way to damnation
more dreadful than the soul of any sin
did ever pass yet between earth and hell?
dost strive to be particularly plagued
above all ghosts beside? is thy pride such
thou scornest a partner in thy torments too?
what fury gave thee boldness to attempt
this deed, for which I will doom thee with a death
beyond the Frenchmen's tortures.
I smile at thee
draw all the death that ever mankind suffered
unto one head to help thine own Invention
and make my end as rare as this thy Sin
and full as fearful to the eyes of women:
my Spirit shall fly singing to his lodging
in midst of that rough weather; doom me Tyrant,
had I feared death I had never appeared noble
to seal this act upon me, which even honours me
unto my mistress spirit, it loves me for it
I told my heart it would prove destruction to it
who hearing it was for her, charged me to do it
thy glories shall be shortened, who is within there
I called not thee thou enemy to firmness

stage.l: Enter the Ghost in the same form as the lady is drest in the Chayr

sp.l: mortalities earthquake
welcome to mine eyes
as in the day-spring from the mornings
womb unto that wretch whose nights are tedious
as liberty to Captives, health to labourers
and life still to old people, never weary of it,
So welcome art thou to me: the deed is don
thou Queen of spirits, he has his end upon him,
thy body shall return to rise again
for thy Abuser falls, and has no power
to vex thee farther now
my truest love
Live ever honoured here, and blessed above.
o if there be a hell for flesh and spirit
it is built within this bosom: my lords treason
now death, I am for thee, welcome
your king is poisoned
the king of heaven be praised for it
lay hold on him
on Gouianus
even with the best loves
and truest hearts that ever Subjects owed
how is that, I charge you both lay hands on him
look you my lord your will shall be obeyed
here comes another, we will have his hand too.
you shall have both mine, if that work go forward
beside my voice and knee:
Heluetius? -- then my destruction was confirmed amongst them
premeditation wrought it: o my Torments:
Live Gouianus long our virtuous king
that thunder strikes me dead
I cannot better
reward my Joys than with astonished silence
for all the wealth of words is not of power
to make up thanks for you my honoured lords:
I am like a man plucked up from many waters
that never looked for help, and am here placed
upon this cheerful mountain where prosperity
shoots forth her richest beam
long injured lord
the tyranny of his actions grew so weighty
his life so vicious!
to which this is witness
monster in sin, this, the disquieted body
of my too resolute child in Honours war
that he became as hateful to our minds
as death is unwelcome to a house of riches
or what can more express it
well he is gone
And all the kingdoms evils perish with him
and since the body of that virtuous lady
is taken from her rest, In memory
of her Admired mistress, it is our will
it receive honour dead, as it took part
with us in all afflictions when it lived:
here place her in this throne crown her our Queen
the first and last that ever we make ours
her Constancy strikes so much firmness in us:
That honour done let her be solemnly
borne unto the house of peace from whence she came
as Queen of Silence; o welcome blessed Spirit

stage.l: The Spirit enters agen and stayes to go out with the body

sp.l: thou needst not mistrust me, I have a care
as jealous as thine own, we will see it done
and not believe report, our zeal is such
we cannot reverence chastity too much
lead on; I would those ladies that fill Honours rooms
might all be born so honest to their tombs.
